results.title: The Playful pandas
results.brief_description: Shows some of the characteristics and behaviour of pandas through the story of two pandas, Ling Ling and Sang Siang in the National Zoo in Washington D.C. Using whimsical dialogue, the other zoo animals try to find out what makes the pandas so special.

results.title: Play better golf. Part I. Fundamentals
results.brief_description: Championship players, Lloyd Mangrum, Sam Snead, Patty Berg, and Jim Ferrier illustrate, by slow motion, sequences and close-ups, the three fundamentals of good golf - correct grip, aim and swing.
results.description: Championship players, Lloyd Mangrum, Sam Snead, Patty Berg, and Jim Ferrier illustrate, by slow motion, sequences and close-ups, the three fundamentals of good golf - correct grip, aim and swing.

results.title: Play better golf. Part II. Advanced
results.brief_description: Lloyd Mangrum, Sam Snead, Patty Berg and Jim Ferrier show applied techniques in overcoming hazards and obstacles likely to be encountered on the course - high grass, water hazards, tree blocks and sand traps. Special attention is paid to proper clubs, chip shots and putting.

results.title: Plants and light
results.creator_credit: Jan Calabek, Milan Hachla and Czechoslovak State Film
results.brief_description: With light all plant life would be limited to fungi, for light, like water, is essential to plant growth. Experiments with potatoes demonstrate how, as spring approaches, stalks feel their way towards the nearest light source. Explains that light is essential because it is the means by which the leaves can produce starch from water and carbon dioxide. Uses time lapse photography.

results.title: Lacock
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “A Place in the Country”.
Part of a series of films made in co-operation with the National Trust, this episode looks at Lacock through the eyes of the family who has lived there.

results.title: Piping hot
results.creator_credit: John Halas, Gas Council and Halas and Batchelor Cartoon Films
results.brief_description: Delightfully inventive treatment of the history of water heating. Reminiscent of “Romance of Transportation in Canada”, the visual, literal representation of straight commentary. Beautifully drawn and a decidedly funny cartoon.

results.title: Pipeline to the Clouds
results.brief_description: Shows the problems of water conservation and distribution. Animated cartoon show various means of finding and storing water. Reveals the wide use of water for industry. Suggests the establishment of nations ‘grids” of water pipes as a solution to the shortages recurring in many areas. Urges economy, mentioning that an average city can lose 500,000 gallons in a day through faulty plumbing.

results.title: The Pilgrims
results.creator_credit: John Barnes and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description: A recreation of the events leading to the settlement of the first English colony in New England. Shows the hardships of the first winter on Cape Cod, the problems of government as solved by the Mayflower Compact, the relationship between the settlers and the native Americans, and the celebration of the first Thanksgiving.

results.title: Pictures of France: Roussillon
results.creator_credit: Max Sautet and French Government Tourist Office
results.brief_description: A rugged landscape compounded of vineyards, rocks and mountains forms the province of Rousillon. At Perpignon, carnival festivities with dancing, masks and fireworks, culminate in a solemn Easter procession through the streets. Traces of various cultural influences remain today in the colour of the bullring and the quaint abbey town with rock-hewn walls and narrow streets. This rich variety of life and architecture makes a painters’ paradise, as ancient traditions are kept alive.

results.title: Picasso (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Anthony Flanagan, Michael Redington and Associated Television
results.brief_description: Sir Kenneth Clark introduces paintings by the Spanish painter Pable Picasso. Filmed in the Tate Gallery, London, where the paintings are displayed in chronological order, we see how, as he matured, his approach changed. From 30 selected paintings, Sir Kenneth shows Picasso’s earliest work, while still in his teens, through various impressionistic works and the great era of his murals to his present works.
